Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Current and Next Generation Mask Elastomer Straps: Mechanical Integrity with Sterilization and Reuse

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: This COVID-19 Rapid Response Research (RAPID) grant will investigate how sterilization and reuse strategies for personal protective equipment used by healthcare workers affect the properties of mask straps. Single use N95 and other masks are in short supply in the US and globally, which has stimulated interest in their sterilization and reuse. In addition to the sterilization procedure killing viruses, it is important that the mask retains a known fraction of functionality including mechanical durability over multiple sterilizations. Sterilization treatments have the possibility of degrading mask materials, in particular elastic straps, which have been identified as a weak link in initial studies. This project will contribute to this important, global need by studying the effects of various sterilization treatments on the structure and properties of strap materials to ensure safe and reliable fitting of masks that will be reused a limited number of times prior to disposal. Additionally, there will be a need for technology developed in this project in low to middle income countries that transcends the immediate crisis and will impact emergency care situations world-wide for years to come.<br/><br/>The goal of this work is to correlate the type and extent of sterilization treatment with the properties of the elastomeric straps. To accomplish this, materials characterization experiments will be performed that establish links between changes in material structure and properties to the combined effects of the sterilization method used and the mechanical deformation associated with donning and doffing. Specifically, chemical changes will be evaluated using thermal and spectroscopic methods that quantify the extent and the spatial distribution of the changes as a function of exposure dose and time. Complementary testing of viscoelastic and mechanical properties will evaluate changes in performance because of sterilization. Beyond characterization of the straps, the integrity of the attachment to the mask will be measured using mechanical testing. The results of this work will provide a more complete understanding of strap degradation for each sterilization method, thereby informing the design of sterilization processes and mask components to optimize the effective mask lifetime. Furthermore, should this work conclude that strap integrity is the limiting factor in the lifetime of a given N95 mask, understanding these underlying failure mechanisms will provide insight into the development of feasible material alternatives or modifications that can be made to extend overall mask lifetime.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, many types of personal protective equipment (PPE) for healthcare workers and the public were in short supply. As a way to address these critical supply shortages, N95 masks were reused in healthcare settings following decontamination treatments. In some cases, the decontamination process was as simple as storage in a paper bag for a period of time, and in other cases, decontamination was accomplished using active treatments. These active treatments had the potential to negatively affect the materials used to construct the masks, and among the materials in the N95 mask assembly, the materials used to make the mask straps could be particularly susceptible to changes in structure and properties when subjected to some decontamination treatments. Therefore, the intellectual merit of this project was an understanding of how a subset of decontamination treatments affected the mask strap material and an evaluation of alternate materials that may be better suited for a mask that is designed for reuse.

In this research, commercial N95 mask straps were subjected to decontamination treatments with ozone, heat, or ultraviolet radiation (UV), and then their structure and properties were characterized to assess if the decontamination treatment caused any negative effects. The commercial mask straps were made of polyisoprene. Additionally, a surrogate material with a similar material composition and larger thickness was treated and tested for comparison. The results of these tests showed that the commercial mask straps were able to withstand limited exposure to ozone, but the surrogate material was more resistant to ozone, likely due to the increased thickness. Both the commercial mask straps and the surrogate material tolerated decontamination with heat or UV exposure better. These results showed that decontamination with heat or UV, as opposed to ozone, would be better options for use with current mask designs, but if the mask strap thickness could be increased, ozone treatment could be tolerated for a limited number of reuse cycles. Also, the results of this research showed that mechanical testing was the most sensitive way to determine if damage to the material had occurred during decontamination. Other testing methods were not able to detect structural changes that would lead to failure following decontamination cycles.

Aside from experiments with the commercial mask straps and the surrogate material, two alternate materials were investigated, silicone rubber and ethylene propylene diene monomer rubber (EPDM). These materials were found to be resistant to decontamination with ozone or heat, suggesting that these materials may be suitable as replacement materials if the masks were to be redesigned with reuse in mind.

Considering the broader impacts of this research, these results suggested that ozone, heat, or UV treatment could allow for a limited number of reuse cycles for N95 masks, which ultimately helps protect medical workers and others during a pandemic. While PPE shortages in the US have been somewhat resolved, PPE reuse is still a topic of interest as it relates to the safe handling of COVID-19 cases and could become relevant again in the event of another pandemic. Additionally, parts of the world with limited resources and large population densities could benefit from practical, low-cost reuse strategies for N95 masks and other PPE. Knowledge of what materials allow reuse and guidelines for the number of reuse cycles provides critical technology now and could allow for the redesign of these masks to reduce the use of single use plastics and potentially reduce the cost of PPE for global healthcare needs.
